+0000","feedId":13983,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f52a2b47ed0ee001e25da8b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"857160bdfcfc4d45c75918297debfb2f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn86@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-12-676_3291b2f5281f5876.webp","destWidth":1440,"destHeight":1080,"sourceBytes":45992,"destBytes":45992,"author":"insider@insider.com (Robert Leslie)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f52a218e6ff30001d4e73ed?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn5@2020_6/2020/09/05/09-01-16-260_293e907b8c562e13.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f52a26e7ed0ee001e25da89?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn73@2020_5/2020/09/05/09-01-16-042_ffd2f8c5fed52d8d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f52a2847ed0ee001e25da8a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn15@2020_5/2020/09/05/09-01-15-430_889fbf4cf5634762.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn60@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-18-751_00f09200df8426be.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=j-WrXQ83tjk:NLU47YDck-M:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn24@2020_2/2020/09/05/09-01-15-532_1a3ba3823308c452.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=j-WrXQ83tjk:NLU47YDck-M:V_sGLiPBpWU":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=j-WrXQ83tjk:NLU47YDck-M:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn13@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-19-304_001c60b57ae65f9e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn54@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-18-350_767e235117808cfa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn12@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-17-769_edf0fa9b5dde1c97.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/clusterstock/~4/j-WrXQ83tjk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/05/09-01-16-523_c7f1db0fa4c972e5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599296467312},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","title":"First-term Rep. Colin Allred squares off against Genevieve Collins in Texas' 32nd Congressional District","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/texas-32nd-district-house-election-colin-allred-genevieve-collins-2020","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f3ee23c89aff80028ab700c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Colin Allred\" height=\"1392\" width=\"2784\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Members chant H.R.3 during President Donald Trumps State of the Union address in the House Chamber on Tuesday, February 4, 2020. The chants were in reference to the House-passed bill requiring Medicare to negotiate for lower drug prices.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call, Inc via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>First-term Rep. Colin Allred will face Republican Genevieve Collins in Texas' 32nd Congressional District.</li>\n<li>The district was established in 2003 after Texas added two more congressional districts following the 2000 U.S. Census.</li>\n<li>Allred is the first Democrat to represent the state's 32nd Congressional District.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>First-term <strong>Rep. Colin Allred</strong> looks to defend his new seat against Republican <strong>Genevieve Collins</strong> in Texas' 32nd Congressional District this fall.&#160;</p><h2>The candidates</h2><p>Allred, the incumbent, is a former football player of the National Football League. After four years with the Tennessee Titans, Allred retired and became an attorney and worked as a <a href=\"https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/berkeley-law-alum-and-former-nfl-player-colin-allred-on-following-obama-the-american-dream-and-his-path-back-to-dallas/\">special assistant</a> in the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Office of General Counsel during the Obama Administration. In 2018, he defeated eight-term incumbent Pete Sessions to become the first Democrat to represent the district.</p><p>Collins, Allred's Republican challenger, is the head of corporate strategy at Istation, an education technology firm. Her <a href=\"https://www.gcforcongress.com/issues\">campaign platform includes</a> supporting America's allyship with Israel, creating term limits for congressmen and elected officials, and preventing the implementation of socialized medicine.</p><p>During the Democratic National Convention in August, Allred was named as a \"rising star.\" He briefly spoke in a pre-recorded message at the convention, drawing criticism from Collins.&#160;</p><p>\"The party is nervous about where he stands, that they want to give him more of a spotlight,\" Collins said in a conference call with the Trump presidential campaign. \"This district is vulnerable, and Democrats and Colin Allred both know it.\"</p><h2>The district</h2><p>Texas' 32nd Congressional District is located in the northeast region of the state in the Dallas area. The district is home to northeastern Dallas County and a small portion of Collin County. It was formed in 2003 when the state added two new districts following the 2000 U.S. Census.</p><p>The 32nd District is one of many suburban Texas congressional districts that has become significantly more favorable to Democrats as suburban and college-educated voters turn away from the GOP under President Donald Trump.</p><p>While 2012 Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney easily carried the 32nd District by a margin of over 15 points, 57% to 42%, the district backed 2016 Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton by a margin of two points four years ago, <a href=\"https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1whYBonfwlgTGnYl7U_IH31G0JNYQ9QBIjDfqkZHkW-0/edit#gid=0\">according to the Daily Kos.&#160;</a></p><p>As Allred defeated incumbent Republican Pete Sessions by over six points in 2018, Democratic US Senate candidate Beto O'Rourke <a href=\"https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1W_GTNylAZfboZkDeMsJPGlir3aQB64SzlVHjY9Xdnkk/edit#gid=562073942\">carried the district by a margin of over 10 points</a> in his race against GOP Sen. Ted Cruz.&#160;</p><h2>The money race</h2><p>According to the <a href=\"https://www.opensecrets.org/races/summary?cycle=2020&id=TX32TX32\">Center for Responsive Politics</a>, Allred has raised $3.7 million for his campaign, or $1.1 million more than Collins' $2.6 million. Collins has $1.13 million in cash remaining, less than half than Allred with $2.98 million.</p><h2>What some of the experts say</h2><p>The race between Allred and Collins is rated as \"leans Democratic\" by <a href=\"https://insideelections.com/ratings/house\">Inside Elections</a> and \"likely Democratic\" by <a href=\"https://cookpolitical.com/ratings/house-race-ratings\">The Cook Political Report</a> and <a href=\"http://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/2020-house/\">Sabato's Crystal Ball at the University of Virginia Center for Politics</a>.</p><div (Madison Hall,Grace Panetta)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f3ee23c89aff80028ab700c?format=jpeg":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn60@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-18-751_00f09200df8426be.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=NHSAPeTXlU0:GBRKjruoWiU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn43@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-18-822_9009e4fb4b2ea29b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=NHSAPeTXlU0:GBRKjruoWiU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn100@2020_5/2020/09/05/09-01-14-689_335cca78f21042de.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=NHSAPeTXlU0:GBRKjruoWiU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn51@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-16-632_a7336876bc8fa150.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn54@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-18-350_767e235117808cfa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn12@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-17-769_edf0fa9b5dde1c97.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/clusterstock/~4/NHSAPeTXlU0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn15@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-16-270_b154aa6dfcecdac6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599296467308},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","title":"Tour de France notebook: America's champ was eager to race in his stars and stripes this year. Then the pandemic hit.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tour-de-france-american-cycling-champ-alex-howes-covid-pandemic-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f52bdd47ed0ee001e25db1d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Alex Howes US champ alternative racing\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1920\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>With racing on pause this spring, Alex Howes, the reigning US road champion, and Spencer Powlison rode their bikes 14 hours, from Colorado to Kansas.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://joeyschusler.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Joey Schusler via EF Pro Cycling</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>For a decade <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/alex-howes\">Alex Howes</a> dreamed of becoming America's cycling champion, so when <a href=\"https://www.efprocycling.com/alex-howes-us-national-road-champion/\">he finally won the title</a> last year he said it was \"surreal\" and better than he could've imagined.</p><p>But because of the ongoing <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/coronavirus\">coronavirus</a> crisis, the 32-year-old from Golden, Colorado, has been left spinning his wheels with few opportunities to don the red, white, and blue.</p><p>\"I've haven't really raced much in the jersey at all,\" Howes told me by phone this week from his European base in Girona, Spain. \"But at the same time I guess no news is good news.</p><p>\"I'm just the undefeated, undisputed champ,\" he said, laughing. \"You can't take that. If there are no races on, we'll just let the American public assume I'm the best.\"</p><p>Howes, who rides on the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/ef-pro-cycling\">EF Pro Cycling</a> team, had to fly to Europe before travel restrictions took effect. He now finds himself away from friends and family and missing home, in a country that is again seeing a surge in its number of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/covid-19\">COVID-19</a> cases. \"They're left and right,\" he said.</p><p>He hasn't competed this year, except for a couple of small early-season races. He got a stomach virus at the end of July, which meant no <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/tour-de-france\">Tour de France</a>, a race he's ridden twice.</p><p>Howes isn't just another roadie. He often heads off-road and participates in what some call \"alternative racing.\"</p><p>Last year he completed Leadville, the popular 100-mile mountain-bike race in his home state.</p><p>This spring he and a teammate flew to South Africa to race the gnarly Cape Epic, but it got canceled last minute because of the coronavirus.</p><p>Then, before he left the States for Europe, he and a friend <a href=\"https://www.efprocycling.com/due-east-for-miles-and-miles/\">rode their bikes for 14 hours</a>, from the Colorado mountains to the Kansas border. It was something to do while racing was paused.</p><p>Howes said he likes the alt racing because he can do it close to home, and it allows pros to meet everyday cyclists \"somewhere in the middle.\"</p><p>\"That's really important at the moment because there are more people riding bikes right now in America than ever before, which is just incredible,\" he said.</p><p>\"Not only do I want to encourage more people to ride, but I also want to get these people who pick the bike up somewhere during this quarantine business and help them become better and enjoy it more. We want to keep those good habits going anyway we can.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f52afc07ed0ee001e25dada?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Alex Howes EF Pro Cycling\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Howes racing last summer in Utah.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chris Graythen/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>\"Our goals showing up to these quote, unquote alternative events was never to pummel the competition. We're really there more to study and engage than to win. That's not to say that once the flag drops we're not racing. We try as hard as we can. But the result is kind of secondary to the overall experience and process.</p><p>\"That said, it would be nice, now that we've learned a little bit, to try and win one or two, but again, the COVID thing screwed that all up. So 2021, right?\"</p><p>Howes said he's been keeping in touch with his teammates and other riders racing in France. (He has about 100 Tour riders' numbers in his phone, he told me.) Among other things, they talk about rider safety and carrying out their jobs during the pandemic.</p><p>\"With COVID it's been interesting following and talking to various riders, with how they're training camps have gone and what sort of COVID-19 protocols and restrictions they have,\" he said. \"I'd say everybody's taking it pretty serious — certainly with the Tour.</p><p>\"But even with a heightened level of seriousness and caution, there's definitely some teams that are taking it a lot more serious than others, which can make it harder to perform.</p><p>\"And really not even physically. All that kind of stuff is mental. When you get locked in a bubble for a month and a half, I don't care who you are, you're either an astronaut, and you don't care, or you're a normal human, and it drives you insane.\"</p><p>To cut the boredom he's been watching the Tour on television, \"bits and pieces\" anyway.</p><p>Do the pros watch the greatest bicycle race through a special lens?</p><p>\"The biggest thing I find when I watch the Tour, I just watch it and I'm like, 'Man, bike racing is dangerous.' You don't really see it as much when you're in it, you know? It's a different perspective.</p><p>\"I think of it like when you have a teenager driving a car. They're like, 'I got this, it's fine.' And then you're the old lady watching it from the outside, and you're like, 'That guy's going 65 miles an hour in a 35-mile-an-hour speed limit. He doesn't got that.'\"</p><p>Because the US national championships were canceled, it appears as if by default that Howes will keep his \"<a href=\"https://www.efprocycling.com/our-stories/\">fancy shirt</a>\" for another season. He said he's not heard from the governing body, USA Cycling.</p><p>\"I don't think anyone's really working there at the office right now. I didn't get a medal in the mail or anything.</p><p>\"It was just sort of like on Twitter. They were like, yeah, he has the jersey and he can wear it again.\"</p><p>All along, he's been \"training the house down\" for next month's <a href=\"https://www.giroditalia.it/en/\">Giro d'Italia</a>, which he's planning on racing. If all goes well he'll show his American colors in October, a time he'd normally be roaming the woods outside Boulder.</p><p>After a nearly raceless season, starting the Italian tour cold should be interesting.</p><p>\"Oh yeah,\" he said, chuckling. \"I mean, luckily everybody else is kind of screwed, too. The awkwardness of COVID-19 is not unique to any one of us at this point.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a We expect similarly excellent deals this year.</li><li><strong>If you want to save now, you can also check out our&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-online-sales-deals\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Deal of the Day</a>&#160;and&#160;<a href=\"https://coupons.businessinsider.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Insider Coupons</a>&#160;pages for current discounts on a variety of products.</strong></li><li><strong>For details on even more deals, you can find all of our&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/prime-day-2020\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Prime Day 2020</a>&#160;coverage here.</strong></li></ul><p>Heads up to anyone who loves to read or plans to spend the bulk of their summer weekends splayed out on a beach flicking through the latest thriller, Prime Day 2020 is going to sneak up on you real quick. That is, with deals to appeal to your bookworm-ish heart and savings-driven brain.</p><p>Prime Day may have been delayed this year until fall 2020, but we still expect to see excellent prices on certain products. Because <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-amazon-prime-day\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the yearly sales event is hosted by Amazon</a>, it tends to favor <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/guide-to-amazon-devices-comparison-of-echo-fire-tablets-tv-kindle-paperwhite-2018-6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon devices</a> and services, and that includes everything Kindle ereaders.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07DLPWYB7/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=biipg_033117_best_ereaders-20&camp=1789&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=B07DLPWYB7&linkId=d0f4283097b9e4a08396f6ca143f6f6a97b9e4a08396f6ca143f6f6a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Kindle</a> is Amazon's collection of tablet-like ereaders. It's also an app that lets you read ebooks from your phone or any other type of tablet. Supplementing the devices and app is <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/kindle-dbs/hz/subscribe/ku/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&linkCode=ll2&tag=biip_071520_2020-amazon-prime-day-20&linkId=2eff17b74bfa8ceee23c3d03637742bf&language=en_USp;language=en_US\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Kindle Unlimited</a>, a monthly membership that gives you unlimited access to more books than you can count.</p><p>To see what it's like to read with a Kindle, you can first read <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-use-kindle-tips\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">our guide to using a Kindle</a>, which includes expert tips and tricks. Then, make sure you're prepared for Prime Day 2020 with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-shop-amazon-prime-day\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">this checklist</a>.</p><h3>Kindle deals we expect on Prime Day 2020</h3>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tKindle Unlimited\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cf044bf11e20512f51778d8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kindle cyber monday deals\" height=\"600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/kindle-dbs/hz/subscribe/ku/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;linkCode=ll2&#38;tag=biip_071520_2020-amazon-prime-day-20&#38;linkId=2eff17b74bfa8ceee23c3d03637742bf&#38;language=en_US\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Amazon Kindle Unlimited, $9.99/month (originally $9.99/month)</a> [Was $30 off a year's subscription on Prime Day last year]</h3><p>Great for particularly voracious readers, Kindle Unlimited gives you unlimited access to over 1 million books, a rotating selection of popular magazines, and thousands of Audible audiobooks. You can access it through any Kindle or device with the Kindle app. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-use-kindle-unlimited\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Learn more about how to use the service here</a>. We expect to see a similar discount for 2020.</p>\n\tKindle\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cf0485211e20567a60a1b34?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kindle prime day deals 2\" height=\"600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07DLPWYB7/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;tag=biipg_033117_best_ereaders-20&#38;camp=1789&#38;creative=9325&#38;linkCode=as2&#38;creativeASIN=B07DLPWYB7&#38;linkId=d0f4283097b9e4a08396f6ca143f6f6a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow\" data-amzn-asin=\"B00N2ZDXW2\">Amazon Kindle, $89.99 (originally $89.99)</a> [Was just $59.99 on Prime Day last year]</h3><p>The most basic Kindle is a solid under-$100 ereader. Though its resolution of 167 ppi is lower than that of its counterparts, the screen is still glare-free, and the newest version now comes with an adjustable front light. This is yet another that isn't discounted at all right now, but could go for tens of dollars off in just a few more months.</p><p><strong>Read the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-kindle-review\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Amazon Kindle review here</a>.</strong></p>\n\tKindle Paperwhite\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5beb435e01b12d67786642ec?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Kindle Paperwhite\" height=\"981\" width=\"1308\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07CXG6C9W/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;tag=biipg_033117_best_ereaders-20&#38;camp=1789&#38;creative=9325&#38;linkCode=as2&#38;creativeASIN=B07CXG6C9W&#38;linkId=2f21df9c38e433bfd4fefe1407c75e12\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow\" data-amzn-asin=\"B00N2ZDXW2\">Kindle Paperwhite, $129.99 (originally $129.99)</a> [Was just $84.99 on Prime Day last year]</h3><p>If you hate lugging around books and your bookshelf is already full to bursting with titles, you'll love the convenience of Amazon's best-selling Kindle device. It has converted many Insider Picks reading snobs who previously proclaimed they could only ever read physical books &#8212; quite the achievement. The newest one is thinner, lighter, and waterproof.&#160;This is another we would wait to see a discount, because it's all but guaranteed.</p><p><strong>Read the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kindle-paperwhite-review\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Kindle Paperwhite review here</a>.</strong></p>\n\tKindle Oasis\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e542079fee23d4378001d33?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Amazon Kindle Oasis\" height=\"1199\" width=\"1599\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Hollis Johnson</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07KR2N2GF/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;tag=biipg_033117_best_ereaders-20&#38;camp=1789&#38;creative=9325&#38;linkCode=as2&#38;creativeASIN=B07KR2N2GF&#38;linkId=d75717e91d2abed63c9834c3bef031bc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow\" data-amzn-asin=\"B00N2ZDXW2\">Kindle Oasis, $279.99 (originally $279.99)</a> [Was just $174.99 on Prime Day last year]</h3><p>Amazon's most expensive and advanced Kindle ereader basically requires a deal to make it worthwhile, which we hope to see again on Prime Day 2020. Without any deals, it's expensive, but we still call it <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-ebook-readers-kindles\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the best ereader you can buy right now</a> because it's incredibly light, has an impressive battery life, and the asymmetrical design makes it easy to turn pages. It has a glare-free, 300 ppi resolution display, plus it's waterproof. Absolutely wait for Prime Day this year before picking this one up (unless you just want on really badly right now, of course).</p><p><strong>Read the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-kindle-oasis-review\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Kindle Oasis review here</a>.&#160;</strong></p>\n</div><div 17:01:07","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","title":"The Trump administration is considering whether to blacklist China's top chipmaker, as the US escalates its crackdown","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-may-blacklist-china-based-smic-trade-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f52b3707ed0ee001e25daf2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump\" height=\"2908\" width=\"3877\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The White House is considering blacklisting a China-based chip maker in the US.</li>\n<li>A Defense Department official said that it may blacklist Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation (SMIC), forcing US companies to get a special license before shipping to the company.</li>\n<li>This would add to the string of blacklists that the Trump administration has put on China-based companies: The list of 275 includes Huawei and ZTE.</li>\n</ul><p>The Trump administration is considering whether to add China's top chipmaker SMIC to a trade blacklist, a Defense Department official said on Friday, as the United States escalates its crackdown on Chinese companies.</p><p>A Pentagon spokeswoman said the Defense Department was working with other agencies to determine whether to make the move against Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation which would force US suppliers to obtain a special license before shipping to the company.</p><p>SMIC did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment.</p><p>The Trump administration has often used the entity list–which now includes more than 275 China-based firms–to hit industry sectors that China prioritizes, from telecoms equipment giants Huawei Technologies and ZTE over sanction violations, to surveillance camera maker Hikvision over suppression of China's Uighur minority.</p><p>SMIC is the largest Chinese chip manufacturer but is second-tier to rival Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd., the industry's market leader. It has sought to build out foundries for the manufacture of computer chips that can compete with TSMC.</p><p>While the Pentagon official did not outline the reasons for the action, SMIC's relationship to the Chinese military is under scrutiny, another US official said.</p><p>Recently the administration has trained its focus on Chinese companies that bolster Beijing's military. Last month, the US blacklisted 24 Chinese companies and targeted individuals it said were part of construction and military actions in the South China Sea, its first such sanctions against Beijing over the disputed strategic waterway.</p><p><em>Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tiktok-cybersecurity-exclusive-idUSKCN256100https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-smic-exclusive/exclusive-trump-administration-weighs-blacklisting-for-chinas-smic-idUSKBN25V2VR?utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=Socialcial\">Reuters</a>. Follow Reuters on <a href=\"https://www.twitter.com/Reuters\">Twitter</a>.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":13983,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f52b33ae6ff30001d4e7450?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"039d5a2cbb36c4899a63bab9cebb0084","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn13@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-12-704_7fd55aeb62251da8.webp","destWidth":4049,"destHeight":3037,"sourceBytes":294728,"destBytes":294728,"author":"insider@insider.com (Idrees Ali, Alexandra Alper)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f52b3707ed0ee001e25daf2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn53@2020_2/2020/09/05/09-01-23-532_0d9ca3868cf7928a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn60@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-18-751_00f09200df8426be.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=tcLXfdG04hU:9me0B7vBP8Y:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn89@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-15-240_18a2a3db17081f1c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=tcLXfdG04hU:9me0B7vBP8Y:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn35@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-24-984_6b888f377bd285c9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=tcLXfdG04hU:9me0B7vBP8Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn76@2020_5/2020/09/05/09-01-17-498_1ad636d5dc932900.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn54@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-18-350_767e235117808cfa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn12@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-17-769_edf0fa9b5dde1c97.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/clusterstock/~4/tcLXfdG04hU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn71@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-24-337_ca06a8c013c89f98.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599296467317},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","title":"Everything you need to know about Oklahoma's 5th Congressional District Race","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/oklahoma-5th-district-house-election-kendra-horn-vs-stephanie-bice-2020","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f52aace7ed0ee001e25dab4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Stephanie Bice\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>In this Sept. 12, 2019, file photo, Oklahoma state Sen. Stephanie Bice, R-Oklahoma City, speaks during a news conference in Oklahoma City. Bice is challenging Rep. Kendra Horn in Oklahoma&#39;s 5th Congressional District\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Sue Ogrocki, File</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>First-term Rep. Kendra Horn will face Republican State Senator Stephanie Bice in Oklahoma's 5th Congressional District.</li>\n<li>Bice defeated businesswoman Terry Neese in a hotly-contested primary runoff for this seat, which includes some of the areas in and around Oklahoma City.&#160;</li>\n<li>Oklahoma's 5th District is one of the most traditionally Republican to currently be held by a Democrat in Congress, with President Trump carrying it by over 13 points in 2016.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>First-term Democratic <strong>Rep. Kendra Horn&#160;</strong>will match up against State Senator <strong>Stephanie Bice</strong> in Oklahoma's 5th congressional district. Bice defeated businesswoman Terry Neese for the Republican primary election on Aug. 5, 2020 to decide the Republican candidate as neither Bice nor Neese received 50 percent or more of the vote in the previous primary election.</p><h2>The candidates</h2><p>Horn, the former Manager of Communication and Media Relations for the Space Foundation, is a founding member of <a href=\"https://www.womenleadok.org/about\">Women Lead Oklahoma</a>, a nonprofit aimed at engaging women voters and getting more women involved in civic life.</p><p>Horn defeated Republican then-incumbent&#160;<strong>Steve Russell&#160;</strong>by just over one percent in a major upset victory in the 2018 midterms. In <a href=\"https://kendrahorn.com/\">her re-election campaign,</a> she's emphasizing protecting and improving healthcare, education, and women's empowerment.&#160;</p><p>In January 2020, <a href=\"https://bluedogcaucus-costa.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/blue-dogs-welcome-reps-ed-case-joe-cunningham-and-kendra-horn\">Horn joined the Blue Dog Coalition</a>, a group of centrist Democrats focused on fiscal responsibility and enacting bipartisan legislation. She <a href=\"https://horn.house.gov/about/\">also serves</a> on the House Armed Services Committee and the Science, Space and Technology Committee.&#160;</p><p>Bice currently represents the state's 22nd district in the Oklahoma State Senate. In that chamber, she serves as Chair of the Senate Finance Committee and touts overhauling and modernizing Oklahoma's liquor laws as one of her biggest accomplishments in the job <a href=\"https://www.biceforcongress.com/about/\">on her campaign website</a>. Her campaign platform emphasizes supporting gun rights, opposing abortion, and improving Oklahoma's infrastructure and education system.&#160;</p><p>Bice defeated Neese, a businesswoman, and the former national co-chair of President Trump's small business advisory council despite the conservative Club For Growth PAC spending heavily in the runoff against Bice.&#160;</p><p>An internal Democratic poll conducted for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and released the day of Bice's runoff win <a href=\"https://dccc.org/polling-case-stephanie-bice/\">showed Horn leading Bice by five points</a>, 51% to 46%, in the district. No Republican internal polls of the race have been released as of yet.&#160;</p><h2>The district</h2><p>Oklahoma's 5th Congressional District is located in the center of the state and includes Oklahoma City, Edmond, Shawnee, and Seminole. The district is also home to nearly all of Oklahoma County and all of Pottawatomie and Seminole counties.&#160;</p><p>Oklahoma's 5th District is one of the most traditionally Republican to currently be held by a Democrat in Congress. In 2012, Republican nominee Mitt Romney carried by the district by 18 points that year, and President Donald Trump carried the district by <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/oklahoma-5th-district-congressional-primaries-live-results-2020-6\">13.4 percentage points</a> in the 2016 election, <a href=\"https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2012/11/19/1163009/-Daily-Kos-Elections-presidential-results-by-congressional-district-for-the-2012-2008-elections\">according to the Daily Kos.&#160;</a></p><h2>The money race</h2><p>The long and drawn-out primary runoff between Bice and Neese allowed Horn to amass a considerable cash advantage over Bice. According to the <a href=\"https://www.opensecrets.org/races/summary?cycle=2020&id=OK05OK05\">Center for Responsive Politics</a>, Horn has raised $3.6 million and has $2.6 million in cash on hand compared to $1.45 million raised and less than $80,000 in cash on hand for Bice.&#160;</p><h2>What some of the experts say</h2><p>The race between Horn and Bice is rated as a \"toss-up\" by <a href=\"https://insideelections.com/ratings/house\">Inside Elections</a>, <a href=\"https://cookpolitical.com/ratings/house-race-ratings\">The Cook Political Report</a>, and <a href=\"http://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/2020-house/\">Sabato's Crystal Ball at the University of Virginia Center for Politics</a>.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original 17:01:07","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","title":"Fox News reported Trump never said that dead US troops were 'suckers,' but the network's national security correspondent said ex-officials confirmed he did","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/fox-news-correspondent-confirms-trump-said-dead-us-troops-losers-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e971e4c92e8ba5de8524e1b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump on April 14.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Leah Millis/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Atlantic reported on Thursday that President Donald Trump made derogatory remarks about fallen members of the military, going so far as to call them \"suckers\" and \"losers.\"</li>\n<li>Fox News on Friday said the report was fabricated and criticized The Atlantic's use of anonymous sources.</li>\n<li>However, one of its own &#8212; national security correspondent Jennifer Griffin &#8212; said parts of the damning report, which cited two ex-Trump administration officials, were verified to her.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li>\"According to one former senior Trump administration official: 'When the President spoke about the Vietnam War, he said, 'It was a stupid war. Anyone who went was a sucker,'\" Griffin tweeted.</li>\n<li>Griffin also reported learning that Trump \"just hated\" Sen. John McCain and thought it was \"not a good look\" to include the \"wounded guys\" in a July 4 military parade.</li>\n<li>Trump appeared to be aware of Griffin's reporting and demanded Fox News to fire her.</li>\n<li>Journalists who covered the White House responded by defending Griffin's credentials and her reporting.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Fox News spent a chunk of its Friday coverage dismissing a report in The Atlantic saying President Donald Trump <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-called-marines-died-wwi-losers-suckers-report-2020-9\">belittled fallen military members</a> by calling them \"suckers\" and \"losers.\"</p><p>Then Jennifer Griffin, a national security correspondent for the network, said in a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/JenGriffinFNC/status/1301975321495973889\">lengthy Twitter thread</a> that former Trump administration officials confirmed the president's remarks to her.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-americans-who-died-at-war-are-losers-and-suckers/615997/\">The Atlantic article</a> cited anonymous sources, and Fox News's own sources suggested the article had been falsified. But two former senior Trump administration officials later verified the president's disparaging comments, Griffin said.</p><p>\"According to one former senior Trump administration official: 'When the President spoke about the Vietnam War, he said, 'It was a stupid war. Anyone who went was a sucker,'\" Griffin tweeted.</p><p>This source also described \"a character flaw\" of the president, saying, \"He could not understand why someone would die for their country,\" Griffin added.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Jennifer Griffin  (@JenGriffinFNC) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301975321495973889?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Trump made the comments during a 2018 visit to Paris to mark the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I, according to The Atlantic. Griffin said one of her sources told her the president was in a foul mood and asked why he had to visit two cemeteries during the visit.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Jennifer Griffin  (@JenGriffinFNC) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301975326805897216?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Trump was scheduled to visit Aisne-Marne American Cemetery near Paris that November but said the trip was called off because \"the helicopter couldn't fly\" and that the Secret Service wouldn't drive him to the cemetery. Griffin learned, however, that Trump \"just didn't want to go,\" she wrote on Twitter, citing an unnamed source.</p><p>One of the sources also confirmed that the president said during a planning session that it was \"not a good look\" to include the \"<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-didnt-want-wounded-veterans-military-parade-report-2020-9\">wounded guys</a>\" in a July 4 military parade, Griffin reported. She also said she found out that Trump \"just hated\" <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-falsely-claimed-didnt-call-john-mccain-loser-2020-9\">Sen. John McCain</a>.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Jennifer Griffin  (@JenGriffinFNC) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301975330048167936?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>This corroboration comes on the heels of Trump, his family, and his advisers staunchly denying The Atlantic's story and framing it as a political attack by a biased magazine.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Donald J. Trump  (@realDonaldTrump) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301710816979357697?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Donald J. Trump  (@realDonaldTrump) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301710819349204992?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Donald J. Trump  (@realDonaldTrump) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301893907295371266?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Donald Trump Jr.  (@DonaldJTrumpJr) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301924411176611841?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>\"The liberal activists at The Atlantic are uninterested in the truth, and they are only interested in peddling conspiracy-laden propaganda,\" White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany told reporters on Friday. \"No one loves and cares for our servicemen and women as much as President Donald J. Trump.\"</p><p>Trump appeared to be aware of Griffin's reporting by Friday evening. The president took to <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1302083885384249344?s=20\">Twitter</a> to disparage Griffin and demanded Fox News to fire her.</p><p>\"All refuted by many witnesses,\" Trump tweeted with a link to a Breitbart News story. \"Jennifer Griffin should be fired for this kind of reporting. Never even called us for comment. @FoxNews is gone!\"</p><p>Journalists who covered the White House responded to Trump by defending Griffin's credentials and her reporting.</p><p>\"[Griffin] is an excellent reporter and a class act,\" ABC News chief White House correspondent Jonathan Karl said in a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/jonkarl/status/1302084742725144576?s=20\">tweet</a> responding to Trump.</p><p>Fox News chief political anchor Bret Baier also <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BretBaier/status/1302093756913549312?s=20\">described</a> Griffin as \"a great reporter and a total class act.\"</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li>Read more:</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-questioned-kellys-sons-sacrifice-on-memorial-day-grave-visit-2020-9\">'I don't get it': Trump said to have questioned why retired Gen. John Kelly's son fought in Afghanistan — during a Memorial Day visit to his grave</a></li><li><a 17:01:07","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","title":"Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway slashes Wells Fargo stake by 43%","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-slash-wells-fargo-stake-43-percent-2020-9","description":"<p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f52b4417ed0ee001e25daf7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"warren buffett\" height=\"1750\" width=\"3500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Warren Buffett\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Rick Wilking</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><ul><li><strong>Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has sold about 101 million Wells Fargo shares in recent weeks, <a href=\"https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1067983/000119312520240131/0001193125-20-240131-index.htm\">a regulatory filing shows</a>.</strong></li><li><strong>The billionaire investor's company cut its holdings by about 43% to 136 million shares, slashing its stake to 3.3%.</strong></li><li><strong>The sales come after Berkshire sold 25% of its Wells Fargo position in the second quarter.</strong></li><li><strong>Berkshire was previously Wells Fargo's largest shareholder, and Wells Fargo was one of its five most valuable positions earlier this year.</strong></li><li><strong><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></strong><hr></li></ul><p>Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has dumped another 101 million of its Wells Fargo shares, <a href=\"https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1067983/000119312520240131/0001193125-20-240131-index.htm\">according to a regulatory filing on Friday</a>.</p><p>The famed investor's conglomerate already slashed its stake in the banking giant by 25% to about 238 million shares <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-sells-jpmorgan-wells-fargo-buys-barrick-gold-2020-8-1029506182#\">in the second quarter</a>. Berkshire has continued selling since then, cutting its stake by another 43% to 136 million shares, the filing shows. It now holds a 3.3% stake in the bank.</p><p><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\"><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\">Read More:</em></strong><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\">&#160;</em><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-in-real-estate-after-coronavirus-tips-ubs-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-in-real-estate-after-coronavirus-tips-ubs-2020-9\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">A UBS real estate-investing chief told us 5 ways investors can profit from the pandemic's transformation of how Americans live and work — including the housing markets poised to boom</a></em></p><p>Berkshire was previously Wells Fargo's biggest shareholder, owning 323 million shares or a 7.8% stake earlier this year. The bank also ranked among Berkshire's five most valuable holdings earlier just a few months ago.</p><p>Buffett may have soured on the company because of the blow to its reputation from its fake-accounts scandal, and the cap on its assets imposed by federal regulators in 2018, David Kass, a finance professor at the University of Maryland, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-sold-wells-fargo-stock-david-kass-2020-8\">told Business Insider last month</a>.</p><p>Wells Fargo's stock price has slumped about 54% this year to below $25, meaning Berkshire's 136 million shares were worth around $3.4 billion as of Friday's close.</p><p>Berkshire sold a bunch of financial stocks last quarter. It slashed its JPMorgan stake by more than 60%, exited its Goldman Sachs position, and sold shares of BNY Mellon, PNC Financial, US Bancorp, Visa, and Mastercard, among others.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-slash-wells-fargo-stake-43-percent-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?a=tXuvNtCTMS4:B0vWb6H-E9g:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=tXuvNtCTMS4:B0vWb6H-E9g:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?a=tXuvNtCTMS4:B0vWb6H-E9g:cGdyc7Q-1BI\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?a=tXuvNtCTMS4:B0vWb6H-E9g:QXVau8BzmBE\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=QXVau8BzmBE\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/clusterstock/~4/tXuvNtCTMS4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 21:59:00 +0000","feedId":13983,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f52b456e6ff30001d4e745a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"610b65c7a26269a3874a3d7342259dbc","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn53@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-12-672_c8f7c02ef5c474f1.webp","destWidth":3266,"destHeight":2450,"sourceBytes":610818,"destBytes":610818,"author":"tmohamed@businessinsider.com (Theron Mohamed)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f52b4417ed0ee001e25daf7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn39@2020_5/2020/09/05/09-01-25-005_7d018ed46feb6a9b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn60@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-18-751_00f09200df8426be.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=tXuvNtCTMS4:B0vWb6H-E9g:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn65@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-20-288_36e066e14d19c7e2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=tXuvNtCTMS4:B0vWb6H-E9g:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn23@2020_5/2020/09/05/09-01-22-505_7c02af78d9bd59a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=tXuvNtCTMS4:B0vWb6H-E9g:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn49@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-20-224_ebccb376df1eade2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn54@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-18-350_767e235117808cfa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn12@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-17-769_edf0fa9b5dde1c97.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/clusterstock/~4/tXuvNtCTMS4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn45@2020_5/2020/09/05/09-01-17-249_78405674d30d0577.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599296467311},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","title":"Sin stocks are shares in companies whose business can be considered unethical — here's why they're so enticing and the major players","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-are-sin-stocks","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f529285e6ff30001d4e73a4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Sin couple\" height=\"1414\" width=\"2121\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Investing in sin stocks means supporting activities that some people find ethically questionable.\n<p class=\"copyright\">knape/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The &#8220;sin stocks&#8221; label traditionally refers to gambling, alcohol, tobacco, and weapons companies.</li>\n<li>Sin stocks are considered defensive stocks, meaning they tend to perform well even during an economic downturn.</li>\n<li>Though relatively stable, sin stocks carry some special risks, such as being vulnerable to changes in regulations or taxes.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\"><strong>Visit Insider's Investing Reference library for more stories</strong></a><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\"><strong>.</strong></a></li>\n</ul><p>Sin stocks refer to shares of public companies engaged in a business or industry that's considered unethical, immoral, or unsavory. Traditionally, the term's been applied to the weapons, alcohol, gambling, or tobacco sectors. But, with the growth of socially responsible investing and ethical investing, sin stocks now often encompass other companies and industries people find objectionable in some way.</p><p>Some investors shun sin stocks and try to own only investments they consider virtuous or ethical. Other investors favor sin stocks because they tend to perform well in both <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-bull-market\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">bull</a> and bear stock markets, and no matter what <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-business-cycle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">phase</a> the economy is in.&#160;</p><p>Let's fall more deeply into sin stocks.&#160;</p><h2>What is a sin stock?</h2><p>No single standard industry definition exists for sin stocks. But most of the categories could be said to tie into any of the seven deadly sins laid out centuries ago by Pope Gregory I:&#160;</p><ol><li>Pride</li><li>Greed</li><li>Lust</li><li>Envy</li><li>Gluttony</li><li>Wrath</li><li>Sloth</li></ol><p>It's easy enough to plug most of the sin stock categories into this ancient list: Gluttony could refer to alcohol and tobacco stocks, wrath could refer to weapons stocks, and greed could refer to gambling stocks. Adult entertainment companies can also fall under the umbrella of sin stocks, and they fit nicely into the lust category.</p><h2>Is sin in the eye of the beholder?</h2><p>Other stocks and sectors can be considered sinful too — depending on your religion, your politics, and your personal moral and ethical values.&#160;</p><p>For example, Islamic investors, following their faith's Shariah law, might shun conventional financial institutions because they charge interest. Shariah principles also prohibit investments in alcohol, tobacco, pork, gambling, media, and pornography and disallow short selling, speculation, and derivatives.</p><p>Environmentalists might classify oil and coal stocks as sin stocks, considering the companies behind them to be \"polluters.\" Vegans might consider shares of any company that raises animals, sells animal products, or tests on animals to be a sin stock. Some analysts even make a solid argument for Netflix as a sin stock: to binge-watch a show is to indulge in sloth.&#160;</p><p>And if alcohol is sinful, maybe marijuana is, too, if it's being used for recreational and not medicinal purposes. The stock of a company that produces opiates could be considered a sin stock because of all the people who have died or become addicted — though of course, these drugs have enormous benefits too.&#160;</p><p>Even the generally agreed-upon categories can be open to debate. What one person calls a weapons company (unethical) another person might deem a defense company (ethical). Such is the double-edged sword of trying to define what makes a stock sinful.</p><h2>Sin stock categories and companies</h2><p>A variety of corporations could be called sin players.&#160; The categories include the traditional Big Four of the sin stock sector, along with some newer but commonly cited fields.&#160;&#160;</p><ul><li><strong>Alcohol:</strong> Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD), Molson Coors Brewing Company (MCBC), Boston Beer Company (SAM), Constellation Brands (STZ), Diageo (DGEAF), Brown-Forman (BF)</li><li><strong>Defense/Weapons:</strong> Boeing (BA), Northrup Gruman (NOC), Aerojet Rocketdyne (AJRD), Raytheon (RTX), Lockheed Martin (LMT), American Outdoor Brands (AOBC), Olin (OLN), Vista Outdoor (VSTO), Sturm, Ruger (RGR)</li><li><strong>Tobacco: </strong>Altria (MO), British American Tobacco (BTAFF), Philip Morris (PM)</li><li><strong>Gambling/Adult Entertainment:</strong> Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Penn National Gaming (PENN), Caesars Entertainment (CZR), Boyd Gaming (BYD), Scientific Games (SGMS), DraftKings (DKNG), RCI Hospitality Holdings (RICK)</li><li><strong>Marijuana/Cannabis: </strong>Cronos (CRON), Canopy Growth (CGC), Aurora Cannabis (ACB), Aphria (APHA), Tilray (TLRY), GrowGeneration (GRWG)</li><li><strong>Corrections/Prisons:</strong> CoreCivic (CXW), The GEO Group (GEO)</li><li><strong>Payday Lenders:</strong> World Acceptance Corp. (WRLD), Enova International (ENVA)</li><li><strong>Energy:</strong> Energy Transfer LP (ETP), ExxonMobil (XOM), Kinder Morgan (KMI)</li><li><strong>Meat:</strong> Hormel Foods (HRL), Sanderson Farms (SAFM), Tyson Foods (TSN)</li><li><strong>Snacks/Junk Food:</strong> Coca-Cola (KO), Mondelez International (MDLZ), Hershey (HSY), PepsiCo (PEP), McDonald's (MCD)</li></ul><h2>What makes sin stocks enticing?</h2><p>You don't invest in sin stocks just for the thrill of being naughty. Owning them can be an attractive financial strategy.&#160;</p><h3>They're steady performers</h3><p>Sin stocks are considered \"defensive\" stocks, meaning they tend to perform well even during an economic downturn or <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-recession\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">recession</a>. People who regularly smoke, drink, or gamble don't stop doing these things when times are bad, whether because they're physically addicted or because they enjoy these activities as a way to escape and unwind, however un healthfully.&#160;</p><p>And of course, they might indulge even more when times are good.&#160;</p><h3>They're cash cows</h3><p>As a result, sin stocks are known for their stable earnings and income streams. Many companies in sin industries are well-established, have sound financials, and have consistently paid dividends for years.&#160;</p><h3>They've got little competition</h3><p>The goods and services that sinful companies produce tend to be highly subject to law. Potential competitors may be loath to enter such enterprises, creating more room for the existing players.</p><p>Even sin stocks' negative connotations can work to their advantage. Certain institutional investors — especially those handling funds for religious or academic groups — often shy away from notorious or controversial businesses. That can lead to a particular sin stock being undervalued and a good bargain.</p><h2>What are the downsides of sin stocks?</h2><p>Even if you have no moral or ethical qualms about investing in sin stocks, you should consider their potential financial drawbacks before adding them to your portfolio.</p><h3>There's high regulatory risk</h3><p>All companies' fortunes can be contingent on laws, but regulatory risk is a particular concern with sin stocks.&#160;</p><p>Marijuana might become legal at the federal level, but what happens if, instead, U.S. states reverse the legality of medical or recreational marijuana? Defense spending and gun control regulations can change depending on who rules a country, international relations, and terrorist activity.</p><h3>Taxes can be a problem</h3><p>All companies have to deal with taxation, but sin stocks often have a fiscal target on their backs. Regulators and voters could decide to increase taxes on the \"sinful\" items these companies produce; they're often the go-to source when states need money. Higher taxes could reduce demand, dampen profits, and push stock prices down.</p><h3>Consumer habits can change</h3><p>You'll also want to consider the effect of changing consumer tastes, like declining alcohol and tobacco consumption. Black swan events can force habits to change, such as a pandemic shutting down casinos and the sporting events people like to bet on.</p><p>Finally, devoting too much of your portfolio to a single industry or company is always risky, no matter whether that company produces organic vegetables or nuclear warheads.</p><h2>How to invest in sin stocks&#160;</h2><p>The unique consideration for sin stocks is whether you oppose the product or service a company manufactures or purveyors. Otherwise, whether you should invest in sin stocks boils down to the same questions you would ask yourself with any investment:&#160;</p><ul><li>What is the unique benefit of putting my money in this investment versus a different investment?&#160;</li><li>Is the potential reward high enough to choose this investment over the alternatives?</li><li>How does this investment fit into my portfolio and my overall investment strategy?</li><li>How much money do I stand to lose? Can I afford that loss?</li></ul><p>Of course, as with any investment, you'll have to do the research on any possible sin stock you're considering to make sure the conventional wisdom about it holds true.</p><h2>The financial takeaway</h2><p>In a sense, the decision to invest in stocks question touches on the general issue of socially responsible and ethical investing — and whether you feel that your principles should influence your principal.</p><p>Some investors' attitude toward sin stocks is that it's up to individuals to decide whether they want to smoke, drink, or gamble, despite the risks. Other investors think that the companies producing these products are at least partly to blame for individuals' consumption, especially when that consumption becomes addictive and products are engineered to be addictive.&#160;</p><p>It's up to you whether to base your investment decisions purely on financial considerations or whether to let the ethical questions inform your choices.&#160;</p><h2>Related Coverage in&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">Investing</a>:</h2><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/why-invest-stock-market\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Why invest in the stock market? Because it can be more dangerous not to</a></h3><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/how-to-invest-in-stocks-beginners-guide\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How to (Amy Fontinelle)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f529285e6ff30001d4e73a4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn87@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-23-698_b245e7bb74271407.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn60@2020_3/2020/09/05/09-01-18-751_00f09200df8426be.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=6Wh2fyX14xM:oyNiMveMFUQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn85@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-16-735_038fcfe6b769104e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=6Wh2fyX14xM:oyNiMveMFUQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn69@2020_6/2020/09/05/09-01-13-833_75b4d0b98b6fb791.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?i=6Wh2fyX14xM:oyNiMveMFUQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn4@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-22-365_c17287f7ed7a3d32.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn54@2020_1/2020/09/05/09-01-18-350_767e235117808cfa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/clusterstock?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn12@2020_4/2020/09/05/09-01-17-769_edf0fa9b5dde1c97.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/clusterstock/~4/6Wh2fyX14xM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn41@2020_5/2020/09/05/09-01-14-289_9652b865dd9ac272.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599296467314},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 17:01:07","title":"What is Webex? How to get started with the web-conferencing tool for individuals, teams, and businesses","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-webex","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4964f77ffa48002894cf70?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Video conferencing on desktop computer\" height=\"1414\" width=\"1885\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Here&#39;s what you need to know about Zoom competitor Webex&#39;s subscription plans, installation, and meetings platform.\n<p class=\"copyright\">pixelfit/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Webex is a web-conferencing tool that you can use for group video or audio meetings.&#160;&#160;&#160;</li><li>Webex is also a much broader suite of tools that include apps for team collaboration, Voice Over IP phone services, online events, and more.&#160;</li><li>Here's everything you need to know to get started with Webex Meetings, including subscription plans, how to install it, and to host and join meetings.</li><li>&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories.</a></li></ul><p>Zoom's rapid growth means the platform is the one that most people think of when imaging group video conferencing. But Webex is among one of the oldest and most established web-conferencing services in operation.&#160;</p><p>Accessible on mobile and desktop devices, Webex's robust subscription plans and feature sets mean it's still a popular choice for large businesses and enterprises. Plus, with a free tier of service, it's a good alternative for individuals and small businesses.&#160;</p><p>Here's everything you need to know about Webex, including its various subscription plans, and how to download and get started with it.&#160;</p><h2>What you need to know about Webex</h2><p>Webex is more than just a video-conferencing platform; it's a suite of tools and services offered by Cisco.&#160;</p><p>When you think of Webex, you probably imagine Webex Meetings, the online audio and video conferencing system. But Cisco also offers Webex Teams, a messaging, file sharing, and whiteboarding collaboration tool.</p><p>Additionally, the company supports services like Webex Events for hosting virtual events, Webex Calling, a Voice Over IP technology that enables voice calling on any device, and an assortment of other products like Webex Training, Webex Support, and Webex Contact Center.&#160;</p><h2>What Webex Teams costs</h2><p>If you want to use Webex to conduct online conference calls, the good news is that, like most other web conference systems including Zoom, Skype, and Google Hangouts, Webex has a free tier of service, so you can get started at no cost.&#160;</p><p>Here's an overview of the four main tiers.</p><p><strong>Webex Meetings free.</strong> A free account allows a single host to conduct meetings up to 50 minutes with as many as 100 participants. Sessions can be recorded locally on the host's computer, but not to the cloud.&#160;</p><p><strong>Webex Meetings Starter:</strong> Priced at $13.50 per host a month, up to nine people can host meetings up to 24 hours in length for 100 participants. At this tier and higher, online recordings are supported along with a handful of additional features.&#160;</p><p><strong>Webex Meetings Plus:</strong> The main difference is that at this level — which costs $17.95 per host per month — up to 50 people can host meetings.&#160;</p><p><strong>Webex Meetings Business:</strong> For $26.95 per host a month, up to 100 people may host, and as many as 200 people may attend a meeting.&#160;</p><p><strong>Webex Meetings Enterprise:</strong> This level has customized pricing and allows for an unlimited number of hosts and meetings with up to 100,000 attendees.</p><p>You can find additional information about subscribing to Webex Meetings on the <a href=\"https://www.webex.com/pricing/index3.html\">Webex plans page</a>.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4961907ffa48002894cf67?format=jpeg\" alt=\"what is webex 1\" height=\"1062\" width=\"1887\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Webex web site has a handy tool for learning about the pricing based on how many hosts your organization needs.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>Creating a Webex Meetings account</h2><p>When you're ready to get started with Webex, you need to decide if you ever plan to host meetings or only want to join meetings hosted by others.&#160;</p><p>To host, you will need to create an account. To join meetings, you can create an account, but you don't need to.&#160;</p><p>To create an account, go to the <a href=\"https://www.webex.com/pricing/index3.html\">Webex website</a> and click \"Start for Free\" at the screen's top right. Then follow the instructions to create an account.</p><h2>Downloading Webex</h2><p>Depending on how you plan to use Webex, you have a few options for launching the conferencing tool.&#160;</p><p>You can use the service on a computer by installing the desktop app, but that's not essential. Webex can run entirely within a web browser, so you can join meetings without installing anything at all. You can also install the mobile Webex app on your phone or tablet.</p><ul><li>To install the Webex desktop app on your Windows or Mac computer, go to the <a href=\"https://www.webex.com/pricing/index3.html\">Webex website</a>, create an account, and install it. If you've already opened an account but have not yet installed the app, go to the <a href=\"https://meetingsamer31.webex.com/webappng/sites/meetingsamer31/dashboard/download\">Downloads page</a> to install the Cisco Webex Meetings desktop app.&#160;</li><li>You can install the <a href=\"https://apps.apple.com/us/app/cisco-webex-meetings/id298844386\">Webex mobile app for iOS</a> or the <a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.cisco.webex.meetings&hl=en_USn_US\">Webex mobile app for Android</a>.&#160;</li></ul><h2>Getting started with Webex Meetings</h2><p>If you have any experience with other web conference tools, you will probably find Webex Meetings familiar and straightforward to use.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4961bc60bf1f00280794e6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"what is webex 2\" height=\"1539\" width=\"2736\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>If you have a Webex account, which you can get for free, you can start meetings from the website or an app.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li>If you are the host, you can <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-set-up-a-webex-meeting\">start a meeting using the web site, desktop app, or mobile app</a>.&#160;</li><li>If you host a lot of Webex meetings, you might want to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-add-webex-to-outlook\">install the Webex plugin for Outlook</a>, which lets you add Webex information to meeting invites in Outlook. If you schedule appointments in Outlook frequently, this is a lot more convenient than using the Webex app to schedule meetings.&#160;</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-join-webex-meeting\">To join a Webex meeting</a>, you need the email invitation sent by the meeting host. If you don't have it, you may need to ask them to resend it. You can generally choose to join via the desktop or mobile app or within a browser window. If the host uses one of the paid plans, you can also dial in using your phone. Just follow the directions in the email to get started.&#160;</li><li>As the host or participant, you can <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-share-screen-on-webex\">easily \"take over\" the meeting by sharing your screen</a>. Webex lets you share your entire screen, just a selected app or browser window, or an interactive whiteboard.&#160;</li><li>If you are the host, or in the paid tiers of service an alternate host, you can <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-record-webex-meeting\">record a meeting for future reference</a> or to share with invitees who could not attend. After recording a meeting, it will be stored locally on your computer or in the cloud, where you can <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-download-webex-recording\">retrieve and download it for sharing</a>.&#160;</li></ul><p>&#160;</p><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-set-up-a-webex-meeting\">How to set up a Webex meeting on desktop or mobile and invite others to join</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-join-webex-meeting\">How to join a Webex meeting from your computer, the mobile app, or a phone call</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-record-webex-meeting\">How to record a Webex video meeting on any type of account</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-zoom-guide\">What is Zoom? A comprehensive guide to the wildly popular video-chatting service for computers and smartphones</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/do-you-need-an-account-to-use-zoom\">'Do you need an account to use Zoom?': No, but you'll need one to make your own meetings — here's what you need to know</a></h3></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
